interview_tips: for anyone who is fairly new to the field that I think could prove helpful
to newer SE's / grads / those still school: I'm a Principal Engineer, and have a wide array of experience across operations (including release / imple
/ suggestions that could help others, as well, including if you want to indicate anywhere you disagree with the things I've said and make suggestions
any new engineer to host as many lunch and learns, and project demos as they can (code you wrote, tools you wrote, etc
that the game was refined and felt complete before publishing
this in the order I list them for beginners)**
for new LinkedIn users: by default, whenever you view someone's profile, they will see that you did it
only using sites like Indeed and Glassdoor as search engines and then going to the company's website to apply
red_flags: thing but learned from that failure
thing, you knew it, you made the decision, and faced some consequences
like the people interviewing you , find out if they are someone you will have to work with every day or if they are not someone you will work with eve
cover one of your strengths you bring it up when they're done with questions
believe the “worker shortage” narrative - it’s always a lie
neglect your communication skills in favor of improving your leetcode skills
duplicate efforts and enhance a tool that's already in use by the organization
actually indicates any interest in a dialogue or common goal

process_insights.format: Mix of phone screen, technical, behavioral, on-site, virtual
